user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_init:
```c
void
MHD_init (void)
{
#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  WSADATA wsd;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */

  MHD_set_panic_func (NULL, NULL);

#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  if (0 != WSAStartup (MAKEWORD (2, 2), &wsd))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialize winsock.\n"));
  if ((2 != LOBYTE (wsd.wVersion)) && (2 != HIBYTE (wsd.wVersion)))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Winsock version 2.2 is not available.\n"));
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
#ifdef MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT
#if GCRYPT_VERSION_NUMBER < 0x010600
#if GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_pthread))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#elif defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_w32))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#endif /* defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_) */
#endif /* GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00 */
  gcry_check_version (NULL);
#else
  if (NULL == gcry_check_version ("1.6.0"))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("libgcrypt is too old. MHD was compiled for " \
                  "libgcrypt 1.6.0 or newer.\n"));
#endif
#endif /* MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT */
  gnutls_global_init ();
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  MHD_monotonic_sec_counter_init ();
  MHD_send_init_static_vars_ ();
  MHD_init_mem_pools_ ();
  /* Check whether sizes were correctly detected by configure */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  if (1)
  {
    struct timeval tv;
    mhd_assert (sizeof(tv.tv_sec) == SIZEOF_STRUCT_TIMEVAL_TV_SEC);
  }
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  mhd_assert (sizeof(uint64_t) == SIZEOF_UINT64_T);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_init:
#define MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS 1
...
#define SIZEOF_STRUCT_TIMEVAL_TV_SEC 8
...
#define SIZEOF_UINT64_T 8
...
#define MHD_PANIC(msg) do{mhd_panic(mhd_panic_cls,__FILE__,__LINE__,msg);BUILTIN_NOT_REACHED;}while(0)
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
static void
iov_max_init_ (void)
{
  long res = sysconf (_SC_IOV_MAX);
  if (res >= 0)
    mhd_iov_max_ = (unsigned long) res;
  else
  {
#if defined(IOV_MAX)
    mhd_iov_max_ = IOV_MAX;
#else  /* ! IOV_MAX */
    mhd_iov_max_ = 8; /* Should be the safe limit */
#endif /* ! IOV_MAX */
  }
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
#ifdef MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT
#if GCRYPT_VERSION_NUMBER < 0x010600
#if GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_pthread))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#elif defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_w32))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#endif /* defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_) */
#endif /* GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00 */
  gcry_check_version (NULL);
#else
  if (NULL == gcry_check_version ("1.6.0"))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("libgcrypt is too old. MHD was compiled for " \
                  "libgcrypt 1.6.0 or newer.\n"));
#endif
#endif /* MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT */
  gnutls_global_init ();
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The code uses preprocessor conditionals to include only relevant branches (e.g. MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS is defined, so the MHD_W32_MUTEX_ branch is not compiled rather than being unreachable in the compiled binary). All compiled statements can be executed at runtime (the MHD_PANIC calls are only taken on error and the normal-success paths remain reachable). Therefore Rule 2.1 (no unreachable code) is not violated.
